Himmelsbach | UofL's Levitch has unlikely rise

Walk-on Levitch has gotten big minutes so far

Himmelsbach | UofL's Levitch has unlikely rise

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 1:29 a.m. EST November 22, 2014
Buy Photo

U of L versus U Conn at the YUM! Center. U of L players enjoy a video honoring the graduating seniors on the team. L to r, David Levitch, Wayne Blackshear, Anton Gill, Terry Rozier and Mangok Mathiang. March 8, 2014(Photo: By Pat McDonogh, The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

2 CONNECT 5 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Louisville sophomore David Levitch caught the ball near the top of the key and drained a 3-pointer, and the crowd erupted. It was louder than the kind of eruption you hear when a regular player makes a regular 3-pointer. It was more like an aw-that-was-cute-the-walk-on-scored eruption.

Except this was not the end of the game. And it was not a walk-on getting warm and fuzzy playing time to make the crowd warm and fuzzy.

There were more than 14 minutes left in the second half, and U of L had yet to fully pull away from this plucky Marshall team, and Levitch was in the game because Cardinals coach Rick Pitino thought his team needed him in the game.

RELATED: U of L puts in work to top Marshall

RELATED: Instant Analysis | Louisville routs Marshall

"The student body thinks its's a joke," Pitino said, "but I'm playing David Levitch because he does smart things and helps run our offense and he understands defenses. He always does smart things."

When Levitch entered UofL's season opener against Minnesota last week, I sort of smiled and probably made some comment about the walk-on getting playing time. But through three games, and through Pitino's comments, it has become very clear that David Levitch is currently a part of the Cardinals' rotation.

In U of L's 85-67 win over the Thundering Herd on Friday night, he played a career-high 15 minutes, registering six points, two steals and a rebound. The North Oldham High School graduate is averaging 10.7 minutes per game, more than scholarship players like Quentin Snider, Jaylen Johnson, Akoy Agau and Anas Mahmoud.

Did you see this coming, David?

"I really didn't," he said, leaning forward at his locker. "I didn't really ever know. But when [Pitino] put me in the first couple exhibitions and then I got in against Minnnesota, I had to make the best of it."

And Cardinals fans, to this point, can be forgiven for reacting to Levitch like he is a novelty, because that's mostly how they remember him from last season. When he entered games, it usually meant that life was good and a win was imminent and maybe a 3-pointer would splash in for good measure.

Now, though, that reaction must change. You should get used to seeing Levitch on the court this year.

Louisville's Wayne Blackshear gets a steal against Marshall's DeVince Boykins. Nov. 21, 2014 (Photo: Scott Utterback/The CJ)

    "A lot of guys look at him as a walk-on and think he's not gonna play," forward Montrezl Harrell said. "But that's not how it is."

    Last season, Levitch became friends with former walk-on Tim Henderson, one of the heroes of the Cardinals' Final Four win over Wichita State. He watched how Henderson handled his growing role as a rotation playereventually earning a scholarshipand decided opportunity might exist for him, too.

    Levitch had a more fragile frame than Henderson, though. So during the offseason he began an exhaustive weight training regimen filled with squats, dead-lifts and bench presses. At the start of the summer, he could squat 155 pounds six times. Now he can do six repetitions at 185 pounds. He has also added 10 pounds of muscle.

    No, he will still not win any bodybuilding contests, but the gains have ensured that Levitch will not be a physical liability on the court.

    "Besides his having the worst posture in America and the worst hairdo in America, he really does a lot of smart things," Pitino said with a laugh. "He knows how to move the basketball on offense. He knows how to spot up. He can go by people. And defensively, he's a much-improved basketball player."

    And now, it appears, he has carved an improbable role in the Louisville basketball team's regular rotation.

    Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach

    Coach Rick Pitino on Louisville's win against Marshall.
